results.title: Untold stories of civic participation
results.brief_description: This project was funded by the Department of Human Services, (Eastern Metropolitan Region), developed and executed in partnership with MetroAccess at the City of Monash and City of Whitehorse, and Scope. These stories illustrate the valuable contribution people with disabilities can make to their local community.

results.title: This is my thing
results.brief_description:
Diner’s Club is for people with disabilities and where once a month, for Melanie, it provides a sense of independence and a chance to mix within her own social group. She explains some of the problems that arise when people with disabilities attempt to organise a night out for dinner.
This project was funded by the Department of Human Services, (Eastern Metropolitan Region), developed and executed in partnership with MetroAccess at the City of Monash and City of Whitehorse, and Scope.

results.title: Me and Chillelax
results.brief_description:
Helen lives at home with her parents but attends the WATCH centre (Waverley Adult Training Centre for the Handicapped) every day. It is through WATCH that Helen participates in a variety of educational and creative activities, has found new friends and now enjoys a social life outside her family home.
This project was funded by the Department of Human Services, (Eastern Metropolitan Region), developed and executed in partnership with MetroAccess at the City of Monash and City of Whitehorse, and Scope.

results.title: Life's great, thumbs up!
results.brief_description:
Edmund tells his story about family, his sporting interests including bike-riding, his involvement with Alkira (a centre for people with intellectual disabilities), his work as a volunteer at Box Hill Hospital, his love for music, and his role as a member of the L’Arche community.
This project was funded by the Department of Human Services, (Eastern Metropolitan Region), developed and executed in partnership with MetroAccess at the City of Monash and City of Whitehorse, and Scope.

results.title: It's all been great!
results.brief_description:
Wayne is not only a playing member of the local BBC Bowling Club but he also plays tennis and captains a basketball team. Here he speaks of his various achievements, his love of sport and particularly his love for his family.
This project was funded by the Department of Human Services, (Eastern Metropolitan Region), developed and executed in partnership with MetroAccess at the City of Monash and City of Whitehorse, and Scope.

results.title: Inspired
results.brief_description:
Aaron Purnell used to suffer with up to 200 seizures a day. When he elected to have an operation that would stop his seizures, Aaron also knew that he would also end up with a permanent disability. This is his story of living with that disability, his involvement with the Whitehorse Disability Awareness Project and how his best friend Alisha inspired him to make something of his life.
This project was funded by the Department of Human Services, (Eastern Metropolitan Region), developed and executed in partnership with MetroAccess at the City of Monash and City of Whitehorse, and Scope.

results.title: I'm still me
results.brief_description:
Wheel-chair bound is no excuse for Brenda to not get around, to move about - she is motivated and she likes to motivate others. Her philosophy is “I don’t know what tomorrow holds so I’ll do as much as I can today.”
This project was funded by the Department of Human Services, (Eastern Metropolitan Region), developed and executed in partnership with MetroAccess at the City of Monash and City of Whitehorse, and Scope.

results.title: Here and now
results.brief_description:
Depression can be a disability making every day seemingly a challenge just to get through to the next day. Brendan, with help and motivation, has overcome his struggle with depression and is enjoying the here and now - working, new friends and generally feeling good about himself. “Ode to Barry” written and performed by Brendan Forde.
This project was funded by the Department of Human Services, (Eastern Metropolitan Region), developed and executed in partnership with MetroAccess at the City of Monash and City of Whitehorse, and Scope.

results.title: Big hearted kid
results.brief_description:
Cameron through the use of his “talker” tells of his background, his intense shyness as a child and lack of confidence until the age of 23 when Karen, Rhonda and Mel came into his life. He has become a role model for kids aged 6 to 14 who use talkers and an inspiration to all those who work with him in the disability area.
This project was funded by the Department of Human Services, (Eastern Metropolitan Region), developed and executed in partnership with MetroAccess at the City of Monash and City of Whitehorse, and Scope.

results.title: Racconti: La Voce del popolo = The Voice of the people
results.brief_description:
Racconti: La Voce Del Popolo (The Voice of the People) is a powerful living memory and dedication to the lives of hard working Australian/Italians and celebrates the enormous contribution they have made to this country.
Through the Digital storytelling program at the Australian Centre for Moving Image (ACMI) the 10 storytellers were guided through the telling of a personal story using multimedia tools. The participants used their voice as narrative and combined the audio-visual resources of their personal archives (photographs, video footage, text, music and sound) and each storyteller has produced a 3 - 5 minute digital story that explores their experiences of migration and settlement.
Racconti: La Voce Del Popolo (the Voice of the People) was made possible through the partnership of the Italian Federation of Migrant Workers and their Families (FILEF) and the Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI) with the support of the Victorian Multicultural Commission.
